title: Virgin Hotels Las Vegas Review: Not Far From The Strip
description: The Virgin Hotels Las Vegas is a Hilton property that's near the Strip, but the location is quieter and usually requires a car ride to Vegas' main attractions.

html:
Virgin Hotels Las Vegas, which is part of the Curio Collection by Hilton, stands out — for better or worse — as a different kind of Vegas experience.

This hotel’s quieter, calmer vibe can appeal to travelers seeking respite from the chaos found at most other hotels on the Las Vegas Strip. But for other travelers, the hotel’s odd location near — but not on — Las Vegas Boulevard might feel like the worst of both worlds: You’re still largely dealing with Vegas Strip traffic and prices, yet you don’t get the benefit of being able to easily walk back to your room after a night on the town.

I visited the hotel in June 2024 as part of a two-night stay for a company event. Given that, I didn’t pay for the room — but my employer did (cash rates were hovering at about $200 per night that week). Even if you’re fronting your own bill, the price you’ll pay can vary widely. On some nights (such as weeknights in the winter), prices hover just over $100. But on peak nights, such as Thanksgiving weekend, room rates can start at close to $700.

Here’s a look at what you can expect at Virgin Hotels Las Vegas and whether this off-Strip property is worth your time (or Hilton Honors points).

Location

At about a mile from the heart of the action, Virgin Hotels Las Vegas is neither conveniently walkable nor close enough to offer the quintessential Vegas experience.

If you’re the type who loves popping out of your room and into the chaos of Las Vegas Boulevard, this location may feel inconvenient. Sure, you can grab a rideshare or a cab, but traffic on Las Vegas Boulevard can get backed up, so getting around by car might not be as easy as it sounds, especially during peak hours.

That said, if your Vegas trip includes excursions to off-Strip gems like Meow Wolf’s Omega Mart, the Neon Museum or outdoor adventures at Red Rock Canyon, the location might not be a dealbreaker.

Getting there and parking

The hotel is conveniently located near the airport. Assuming no traffic, it’s only about a five-minute drive to Harry Reid International Airport. As is the case with many Las Vegas resorts, there is no dedicated shuttle service.

But if you drive yourself, parking is free. That’s hardly ever the case with other Las Vegas resorts.

Amenities

The amenities at the Virgin Hotels Las Vegas include pools, a spa, gym, beach club, plus multiple shops, bars and restaurants. Travelers on a short getaway might not even need to leave the grounds to have a full itinerary.

Here’s a look at some of the top amenities offered at Virgin Hotels Las Vegas, Curio Collection by Hilton.

A quiet casino

The resort’s 60,000-square-foot casino has 550 slot machines and more than 45 table games. There’s also the Betfred Sportsbook for sports betting.

The casino tends emptier than the ones on the Strip, which can make it feel less exciting. But it’s nice not having to elbow your way to a blackjack table.

A calm pool scene

Similar to the casino, the pool area at Virgin Hotels Las Vegas (which consists of four different pools) is typically less crowded than other Vegas resorts’ party-centric pools.

The most raucous pool of the Virgin Hotels Las Vegas is Kassi Beach Club, a 21+ venue that’s open only on weekends. DJs play music genres such as tropical house and Top 40 hits, but it has more of a laid-back, pool party vibe.

Bottle service is available, and it’s not cheap. A bottle of Grey Goose will run you $350 at Kassi Beach Club before tax and gratuity. Though, that’s a bargain compared to the roughly $800 you’ll pay for the same bottle at Encore Beach Club at Wynn Las Vegas.

Then there’s the main pool, plus two smaller pools called the Terrace Pool and Dish Pool. The latter two tend to close during shoulder season, which isn’t typically a big deal given the main pool doesn’t get too crowded anyway.

But on my visit on a weekday in June, temperatures were soaring over 90 degrees and guests couldn’t even use the main pool because someone had thrown up in it. You can’t fault the hotel for that, but it’s the risk of having a single pool in operation at a resort in Las Vegas.

An impressive gym

The Virgin Hotels Las Vegas gym is far better equipped than many hotel fitness centers. It includes free weights, cardio machines, and yes — a squat rack (it’s rare to find a hotel gym with a proper squat rack).

Dining at Virgin Hotels Las Vegas

There are about a dozen places to eat or drink at Virgin Hotels Las Vegas. Many are chain restaurants, ranging from Dunkin’ to world-renowned Japanese restaurant Nobu.

Other options include a fast casual pizza joint, a juice bar and an open-air Mexican restaurant.

Daily food and beverage credits for certain Hilton elites

Hilton Honors members with Gold or Diamond elite status get a daily food and beverage credit, which can be used at any time at some restaurants on-site. To use it, simply charge your food at an eligible restaurant to your room. At the Virgin Hotels Las Vegas, the credit covers up to $15 per guest (up to two) per day. It works at the following restaurants on Virgin Hotels Las Vegas property:

You don’t necessarily need to be a frequent Hilton guest to earn Hilton elite status. Certain Hilton credit cards offer elite status as a benefit simply for holding the card.

The rooms

The resort has about 1,500 rooms and suites spread across three towers. Although rooms vary in size and specific amenities, all follow the chic design found at most Virgin hotels. That includes the hotel’s patented “Lounge Bed.”

Here’s a look at a room called the “2 Queens Chamber”:

Convenient, modern touches include a JBL bluetooth speaker, plenty of power outlets and a 55” Samsung TV.

Rooms feature a makeup vanity, instead of a desk.

The closet has an iron, an in-room safe and a separate shelf for shoes.

The bathroom is spacious and fairly luxurious with both a rain shower head and a handheld showerhead.

Complimentary amenities include custom products by Red Flower.

Is Virgin Hotels Las Vegas pet-friendly?

The hotel offers dog-friendly rooms, but dogs cannot remain unattended in rooms unless locked in a kennel or carrier.

And keep in mind that “dog-friendly” can take on different meanings depending on the hotel. At this hotel, dogs (aside from service dogs) can pass through public areas if on a leash, though they aren’t allowed to linger.
